materials.raw_text: B: 10 g, Be: 5 g, Co: 20 g, Nd: 2 g, Tm: 4 g

sourcing.instructions: B: Purchase boron powder from a chemical supplier; Be: Obtain beryllium metal from a specialty metals supplier; Co: Buy cobalt powder from a metallurgy supplier; Nd: Source neodymium oxide from a rare earth supplier; Tm: Acquire thulium oxide from a rare earth supplier.
steps: B: Purchase boron powder from a chemical supplier; Be: Obtain beryllium metal from a specialty metals supplier; Co: Buy cobalt powder from a metallurgy supplier; Nd: Source neodymium oxide from a rare earth supplier; Tm: Acquire thulium oxide from a rare earth supplier.

1. Measure out 10 g of boron powder, 5 g of beryllium, 20 g of cobalt powder, 2 g of neodymium oxide, and 4 g of thulium oxide. 2. In a clean, dry mixing bowl, combine all the powders thoroughly using a spatula or mortar and pestle until a uniform mixture is achieved. 3. Transfer the mixture to a ceramic crucible for heating.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure out 10 g of boron powder, 5 g of beryllium, 20 g of cobalt powder, 2 g of neodymium oxide, and 4 g of thulium oxide. 2. In a clean, dry mixing bowl, combine all the powders thoroughly using a spatula or mortar and pestle until a uniform mixture is achieved. 3. Transfer the mixture to a ceramic crucible for heating.

steps: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1200°C. 2. Place the ceramic crucible with the mixed powders in the furnace. 3. Heat the mixture for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and synthesis of the compound.
heating.raw_text: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1200°C. 2. Place the ceramic crucible with the mixed powders in the furnace. 3. Heat the mixture for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and synthesis of the compound.

steps: 1. After heating, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature (approximately 25°C). 2. Do not open the furnace door until the temperature is below 300°C to avoid thermal shock to the crucible.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After heating, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature (approximately 25°C). 2. Do not open the furnace door until the temperature is below 300°C to avoid thermal shock to the crucible.

steps: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the crucible from the furnace. 2. Use a diamond saw to cut the synthesized solid into the desired dimensions (3 x 2 x 7 inches). 3. Sand any rough edges using fine-grit sandpaper for a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, seal the sample with a clear coat to prevent oxidation and enhance durability.
post_processing.raw_text: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the crucible from the furnace. 2. Use a diamond saw to cut the synthesized solid into the desired dimensions (3 x 2 x 7 inches). 3. Sand any rough edges using fine-grit sandpaper for a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, seal the sample with a clear coat to prevent oxidation and enhance durability.
